Description: Calcite base of pillar or libation-tank: this rectangular block on a plinth has been hollowed out in the centre to a depth of 10.5 cm. The Horus name, prenomen and nomen of Ramses II are twice incised along the sides of the piece together with epithets naming Atum and possibly Horus. This block may originally have been the base of a statue or a libation trough. This piece is cracked and broken in several places with severe loss to one side and damage to two corners. It has been restored in modern times. There are no traces of colour.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: The British Museum, 'A guide to the Egyptian galleries (Sculpture)' (London, 1909), 163 (no. 590); K.A. Kitchen, 'Ramesside Inscriptions' 7 (Oxford: Blackwell Press), 98; B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' VIII (Oxford: Clarendon Press), 63.
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1982 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 10. (pl.18)
Condition: Fair (cracked). This piece is cracked and broken in several places with severe loss to one side and damage to two corners. It has been restored in modern times.
